title: DC winter storm snow forecast: 1-2 punch expected to bring snow, sleet, freezing rain to DMV | FOX 5 DC
text: The Brief A storm system will bring a significant snow threat Sunday night into Monday. Snow showers from Friday afternoon wrap up at night, cold and dry conditions expected over the weekend. The storm begins late Sunday night into Monday, bringing several inches of snow, possibly mixed with sleet and freezing rain. WASHINGTON - The Washington, D.C. region is bracing for winter weather with a significant snow threat from Sunday night into Monday. Will there be a refreeze Friday night? While there may be some slick surfaces from afternoon snow and rain showers, most of the area quickly dries out, aided by gusty winds. There should not be too much of a refreeze issue overnight. READ MORE: DC winter snow storm: Timing, how much to expect by Monday When did the snow start on Friday? The first system brought snow to the area on Friday afternoon and evening. Intermittent rain and snow showers began just after 1 p.m. The snow threat continued until 7 p.m. Most of the day was cloudy with high temperatures near 43 degrees. The snow showers and squalls impacted the Friday afternoon and evening commute. Parts of Maryland to the north and west of D.C. saw a coating of snow on the ground by the time the system moved away. By the early morning, some school districts in the area had announced early dismissal plans. READ MORE: Snow threat prompts early dismissals: DC, Maryland, Virginia closures & delays When will the snow start on Sunday? The main event, expected to bring sizable accumulations to the region, will begin late Sunday night into Monday. The storm will start as snow early Monday, then possibly mix with sleet and freezing rain in the morning. "As it looks right now, we'll certainly have the chance for accumulating snowfall of several inches across the DMV all the way throughout the day on Monday," Grenda said. Image 1 of 12 ▼ DC winter storm snow forecast: 1-2 punch expected to bring snow, sleet, freezing rain to DMV How much snow could we get on Monday? The latest forecast shows a widespread four to eight inches of snow possible across much of the D.C. region, with locally more possible. Areas south of D.C. will have a better chance of a mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain. Temperatures will stay in the 30s through Thursday of next week. READ MORE: DMV snow forecast: Winter preparedness on the road Will schools close on Monday because of the snow? The timing of the snowfall could possibly impact the Monday morning drive to work.
